item.title: Trump Says the U.S. Struck a ‘Big Facility’ in Campaign Against Venezuela
item.description: The administration provided no details of what the president said was an attack last week linked to U.S. efforts to disrupt drug trafficking from Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Such an attack would be the first on land since President Trump began his military campaign against Venezuela.

item.title: Mexico Train Derailment Kills 13 People
item.description: The train was carrying around 250 passengers and crew members on a cross-country route linking the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico. Nearly 100 people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:description: Mexican emergency workers rescuing passengers from a train that derailed in the southern state of Oaxaca on Sunday.

item.title: Twins’ Peaks: The Gilbertson Brothers Want to Rewrite Your Country’s Map
item.description: Two brothers, both mechanical engineers, are climbing many of the world’s tall peaks to prove they have been measured incorrectly.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles

item.title: What to Know About Colombia’s Role in the Global Drug Trade Amid Trump’s Feud With Petro
item.description: President Gustavo Petro is locked in a war of words with President Trump over Colombia’s major role in the global drug trade. The issue is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Ramón Campos Iriarte for The New York Times

item.title: How Oil, Drugs and Immigration Fueled Trump’s Venezuela Campaign
item.description: New details of deliberations show how aides with overlapping agendas drove the United States toward a militarized confrontation with Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager, Charlie Savage, Julian E. Barnes and Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, left, and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, right, have been key players, alongside the presidential adviser Stephen Miller, in President Trump’s escalating conflict in Venezuela.

item.title: A Sweeping Look at One Thing That Unites Canada: Winter
item.description: The National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa has a major exhibition of 164 works from around the world depicting winter and the place of people and animals within it.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Jean-François Bélisle with “Winter Woodland” by Lawren S. Harris.

item.title: A Dancing Dictator and Bankers in Chains: The Other Venezuela Blockade
item.description: A crisis more than a century ago involved U.S. aims to assert military supremacy, a hard-partying dictator and frictions among the great powers.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:description: Cipriano Castro, who ruled Venezuela from 1899 to 1908. Known as the “Lion of the Andes,” he defied the great powers of the era.

item.title: Annette Dionne, Last of the Celebrated Quintuplets, Dies at 91
item.description: She was the first to crawl, the first to cut a tooth, the first to recognize her name, and the last to die. And, like her sisters, she resented being exploited as part of a global sensation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Gross
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Marie, Émilie, Annette, Yvonne and Cécile in 1952.

item.title: How Ryan Wedding, a Canadian Olympic Snowboarder, Turned into a Drug Lord
item.description: Ryan Wedding rose to fame as a Canadian Olympic athlete, but the authorities say he became one of the world’s biggest drug lords, who ordered an informant executed.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ryan Wedding, the police said, ordered the murder of an associate who became an informant. The man was shot and killed while dining in Medellín, Colombia.

item.title: Honduran Candidate Claims Fraud After Trump-Backed Opponent Is Declared Victor
item.description: After officials called the presidential race for Nasry Asfura, his rival, Salvador Nasralla, disputed the result and expressed ire over the U.S. role.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Jeff Ernst
item.media:description: Nasry Asfura in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, last month.

item.title: Christmas Around the World in Photos
item.description: The holiday spirit is bringing people together, with celebrations of lights, dance and Santa.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A Christmas Eve service at the Syriac Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Basra, Iraq.

item.title: With Airspace Closed, a Lonely Christmas for Many Venezuelans
item.description: The holidays usually bring home huge numbers from the Venezuelan diaspora. But this year, after international airlines halted almost all service, many people are spending Christmas alone and on edge.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Most foreign flights into and out of Simón Bolivar International Airport, the main airport serving Venezuela’s capital, Caracas, have been canceled.

item.title: Why the Right Is Boycotting Havaianas Flip-Flops
item.description: For decades, Havaianas flip-flops have been a beloved global symbol of Brazilian culture, worn by millions of people each day. They are now ensnared in a political fight.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: The trouble started for Havaianas with the beginning of a new holiday campaign starring the popular Brazilian actress Fernanda Torres.

item.title: Honduras Declares Nasry Asfura, Trump Ally, Winner of Presidential Election
item.description: Nasry Asfura was endorsed by President Trump in a contentious election. His opponent, Salvador Nasralla, said he would not accept the results.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jeff Ernst
item.media:description: Nasry Asfura, the National Party candidate, cast his vote in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Nov. 30.

item.title: Trump’s Seizures of Oil Tankers Challenge Maritime Rules and Customs
item.description: Recent U.S. actions against ships near Venezuela may embolden other countries to seize or detain ships, legal experts said.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S. government seized the Skipper, an oil tanker, in the Caribbean Sea this month after obtaining a warrant from a federal court.

item.title: Trump’s Tanker Crackdown Paralyzes Venezuelan Oil Exports
item.description: Oil exports, the country’s financial lifeblood, have plummeted after the United States took action against three ships that have been used to carry its crude.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Since the Skipper, a tanker carrying Venezuelan oil, was seized on Dec. 10, only two tankers carrying crude appear to have tried to sail beyond Venezuela’s waters.

item.title: In Ontario, the Uplifting Case of a Ballet Company’s Stolen ‘Nutcracker’ Sets
item.description: Ballet Jörgen’s holiday scare reaffirmed its mission: taking the art form to remote towns and outposts where most people have never seen a pas de deux.
item.dc:creator: Martha Schabas and Brett Gundlock
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Tariffs Threaten Canadian Holiday Sales
item.description: Small businesses across Canada have lost out on sales because of the trade war, and many worry about their future.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Ian Willms
item.media:description: Michelle Galletta, the owner of Kiriki Press, an embroidery craft shop in Toronto, has many customers in the United States and is concerned about future trade turbulence.

item.title: In Pursuit of the Monarch’s Magnetic Sense
item.description: The magnetic compass is the last unknown sense in migrating animals. For some scientists, the monarch butterfly is leading the way.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil and Mark Felix
item.media:credit: Mark Felix for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Orders Nearly 30 U.S. Ambassadors to Leave Their Posts
item.description: A union representing career diplomats said such a mass recall had never happened in the history of the U.S. Foreign Service.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration did not give a reason for the recalls and has not publicly announced them.

item.title: Trump Administration Oil Tanker Seizures Are Meant to Force Maduro Out, Officials Say
item.description: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem said the ship seizures were meant to force Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro from power.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: On Saturday, the Coast Guard boarded the Centuries, a Panamanian-flagged tanker that had recently loaded Venezuelan crude oil, reportedly for a Chinese trader.

item.title: Carney Names Financier Mark Wiseman as Canada’s U.S. Ambassador
item.description: Mark Wiseman has held high-profile roles in law, business consulting and finance, and will lead Canada’s efforts to reboot diplomatic relation with Washington at a critical moment.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Mark Wiseman, a Canadian financial executive, has been named Canada’s ambassador to the United States at a crucial moment in relations between the countries.

item.title: What We Know About U.S. Interceptions of Oil Tankers in Venezuela
item.description: A Venezuela-bound vessel fled after rebuffing an attempt by the Coast Guard to seize it, the latest twist in the escalating U.S. pressure campaign against the Maduro government.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via U.S. Homeland Security Secretary
item.media:description: A frame grab from a video posted on social media by Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, showed a helicopter flying over Centuries, another oil tanker, which was intercepted by the U.S. Coast Guard on Saturday.

item.title: As Trump Clings to Tariffs, His Argentine Ally Is Opening Up to Trade
item.description: President Javier Milei is eliminating barriers to what had been a closed-off economy, moving in the opposite direction of his main political ally, President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Lucía Cholakian Herrera and Sarah Pabst
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customers standing in line for the opening of Decathlon, a sporting goods store, last month in Buenos Aires.
